postsData.name:
Rachel Park
Rachel Park
postsData.content:
Micromanagement is Killing Your Team's Wellbeing.
7 Shifts to Show Your Team You Care:

You see it in their eyes.
The spark of creativity dimming.
The energy draining day by day.

Micromanagement isn't just about controlâ€”
it's slowly eroding your team's mental health.

It shows up as:
â†’ Sunday night anxiety
â†’ Fear of making decisions
â†’ Constant second-guessing

But here's the thing:
Your team doesn't need more oversight.
They need psychological safety to thrive.

Here are 7 shifts to go from controlling to supporting your team:

1. Balance Support and Space
â†³ Trust your team to navigate challenges before stepping in
â†³ Be available for guidance while avoiding hovering over daily tasks

2. Build Trust Intentionally
â†³ Demonstrate confidence in your team's judgment through actions, not words
â†³ Support decisions made by team members, even if different from yours

3. Structure Feedback Flow
â†³ Ask for honest input about your leadership style and impact
â†³ Schedule regular check-ins that focus on support rather than surveillance

4. Master Strategic Delegation
â†³ Assign tasks that align with each person's strengths and growth goals
â†³ Give clear context for projects while avoiding prescriptive instructions

5. Create Open Dialogue
â†³ Create safe spaces where team members can share concerns freely
â†³ Build trust through consistent, transparent two-way communication channels

6. Set Clear Standards
â†³ Define success metrics upfront so your team knows what matters
â†³ Allow flexibility in how team members achieve these agreed outcomes

7. Encourage Creative Freedom
â†³ Create space for new ideas by stepping back from detailed processes
â†³ Celebrate innovative approaches, even when they differ from tradition


Your team's well-being matters more than control.

Trust them to shine their own way.

What's one shift you'll make this week? Share below 


 If you enjoyed this content, you might like my newsletter here:

___

 Follow mefor more posts on career & wellbeing.
ï¸ Repost to support your network.

comments.commentText:

postsData.content:
Marketing Is Fuel

Another bonus of my keynote at VTEX, was that I got to meet and hang out with.

Like me, he was flown down to SÃ£o Paulo, Brazil.

In his keynote address, he shared, "The best form of marketing isn't marketing. Think of marketing as fuel and imagine your product as a car. Assuming you have an amazing car, fuel will get you further."

That stuck with me and Iâ€™ve been using that insight ever since.

As a coach, when Iâ€™m working with my clients I never forget that the transformation with my clients is my product.

A post like this on LinkedIn is simply fuel to help remind others that I exist in the world and seek to serve my niche.

My ultimate â€œwhyâ€ is simple: Iâ€™m here to eradicate scarcity and help every person tap into their infinite abundance.

Sharing this mission is the best fuel I can use to connect with others and help more coaches.

Whatâ€™s your fuel?

If you like this post, please follow

comments.commentText: Bill Carmody, PCC, love this fuel analogy. When our mission truly ignites our passion, marketing flows naturally. Have you discovered what keeps your engine running smoothly?

Andrew Tallents Ah, yes. You want to know about the OIL . What keeps my engine running smoothly is my own mental fitness. My thoughts and my thoughts alone stop me from "Loving What Is" as Byron Katie would say

I agree with this -- I've always focused heavily on my product, knowing that when I deliver a great product and experience, that becomes the best form of marketing because it spreads by word of mouth!
Brynn Smith, CHPC And word of mouth is by far the best form of marketing, Brynn. You're totally right! Thanks for adding that insight to this post.

postsData.content:
â€œWhat youâ€™re doing is risky.â€

I hear this a lot.

Some mean well.

Others, not so much.

â†’ There arenâ€™t many speaker coaches.
â†’ There arenâ€™t many keynote speakers.
â†’ There are many struggling entrepreneurs.

I get it.

But, where most saw risk, I saw the only path.

Because this statement ignores an important fact.

Accepting a life you donâ€™t enjoy is risky too.

Far more Iâ€™d argue.

Because, itâ€™s accepting regret.

And, thatâ€™s something that youâ€™ll always live with.

P.S. What do you think is the bigger risk?
postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely! Embracing passion over fear is vital. Living with regret is the true risk. Letâ€™s dare to follow our dreams! #FearlessLiving

postsData.name:
Fatou Seck Mathon
Fatou Seck Mathon
postsData.content:
7 worst things to do when exiting an employee.
(and how to handle it to preserve their dignity).

Letting someone go is not just a business decision.

It's a critical moment that impacts their life.

Handled poorly, it damages trust, team's morale, and your reputation.

Here are the 7 worst things to do when exiting an employee:
(and how to handle it to protect their dignity)

1. Being cold and impersonal:
 Treating someone like just another name on a spreadsheet.
 Acknowledge their contributions and recognize their work.

2. Rushing through it:
 Delivering the news quickly and moving on.
 Give them time to process and stay available.

3. Choosing the wrong timing:
 Giving them the bad news on a Friday or before a holiday.
 Pick a time when they have space to plan their next steps.

4. Making it public:
 Asking them to pack their things in front of everyone.
 Provide privacy. Let them leave with dignity.

5. Offering zero support:
 Saying "Good luck" and walking away.
 Offer guidance, career resources, or a recommendation.

6. Sounding robotic:
 Reading from a script and avoiding eye contact.
 Speak honestly. Show that you care.

7. Ignoring team impact:
 Pretending nothing happened while your team is in shock.
 Be transparent. Address concerns and reassure your team.

Treat people the way you want to be treated.

Lead with empathy, even in the hardest moments.

What would you add as the worst thing to do?


Repost to help a leader exit employees with empathy.
Followfro more.

comments.commentText: Letting someone go is never just a process; itâ€™s a defining leadership moment that reveals your true character. Great insights, Fatou Seck Mathon! The way you handle an exit speaks volumes about the message it sends to those who stay.
comments.userName: Damesha Craig, Leadership Coach and Startup Advisor

postsData.commentAdded: This is a crucial topic! Prioritizing empathy during exits fosters trust and maintains morale. Itâ€™s the human touch that truly matters.

postsData.name:
Machine Learning Community (Moderated)
Machine Learning Community (Moderated)
postsData.content:
DeepSeek vs ChatGPT: Key Differences

1. Developer
DeepSeek AI: Developed as an open-source LLM.
ChatGPT: Proprietary model developed by OpenAI.

2. Model Type
DeepSeek AI: Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) architecture.
ChatGPT: Transformer-based (GPT-4).

3. Training Data
DeepSeek AI: Multilingual with a strong focus on Chinese.
ChatGPT: Extensive multilingual training, with strong performance in English.

4. Performance
DeepSeek AI: Efficient and cost-effective, optimized for coding and technical tasks.
ChatGPT: Excels in reasoning, creativity, and text coherence.

5. Strengths
DeepSeek AI: Best for coding, programming, and technical applications.
ChatGPT: Ideal for conversational AI, creative writing, and coding assistance.

[Explore more in the post]

postsData.commentAdded: Great comparison! Each model has its unique strengthsâ€”excited to see how they continue to evolve in the AI landscape! #AI #MachineLearning

postsData.name:
James R. Elliot
James R. Elliot
postsData.content:
How to Avoid Burnout and Build a Business You Love

Being an entrepreneur doesnâ€™t have to mean sacrificing your health, energy, or happiness. Yet, many find themselves stuck in the trap of hustle and grind, building businesses they end up resenting.

The key to long-term success is working smarter, not harder. Hereâ€™s how to avoid burnout and create a business you truly love.

The Trap of the Corporate Grind

I realized the mindset of working nonstop to prove your worth was ingrained in me. The constant â€œhustle, hustle, hustleâ€ mentality teaches us that success equals hard work.

The Cost of Not Reworking Your Business

Many entrepreneurs fall into the trap of creating businesses they later feel trapped by. Overworking, burnout, and poor health become common outcomes. The very reason many start businessesâ€”freedom and lifestyleâ€”gets lost in the chaos of never-ending to-do lists.

The Risk of Staying in the Same Pattern

Without self-reflection and adjustments, entrepreneurs risk staying stuck in the same exhausting cycle. Itâ€™s crucial to rethink your business structure and mindset to avoid ongoing struggles.

Signs of Burnout and How to Address It

Burnout can sneak up on you. Many donâ€™t realize theyâ€™re heading toward burnout until itâ€™s too late. To address this, identify the tasks you love and those that drain you.

Delegate or automate the draining ones. Outsourcing can be scary, but it can give you back your time and energy when done right.

Practical Tips to Restructure Your Business

Automate or eliminate low-value tasks.

Focus on what truly drives growth.

Start smallâ€”small tweaks can lead to big changes.

Building a business you love starts with working smarter, not harder.

Prioritize your well-being and watch your business thrive.
postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Rethinking our approach is essential. Prioritizing well-being truly paves the way for sustainable success. #WorkSmart #Entrepreneurship

postsData.name:
steven kamensky
steven kamensky
postsData.content:
Happy Sunday, everyone!  This day is a giftâ€”an opportunity to pause, reflect, and realign. Take a moment to think about the week thatâ€™s just passed. What went well? What could have gone better? Celebrate your victories, no matter how big or small, and recognize the lessons learned from the challenges. Growth comes from both success and struggle.
As we head into the upcoming week, letâ€™s take time to plan with intention. What are the goals you want to achieve? How can you show up as the best version of yourself? Whether itâ€™s in your work, personal growth, or relationships, set a positive mindset for the days ahead.
But donâ€™t forget, Sundays are also about balance. Itâ€™s so easy to get caught up in the hustle, but today, make sure youâ€™re taking time to reset and recharge. Be present with the people you love. Laugh, share stories, and create memories. Those moments with family and friends are precious and can fill your heart with the energy you need to tackle the week.
Let today be a reminder that rest is just as important as productivity. Find your calm, refresh your spirit, and step into the new week with purpose and peace. 
Hereâ€™s to a fresh start, to setting new intentions, and to making the most of every moment with those who matter most. Have an amazing week ahead!

postsData.name:
Marsden Kline
Marsden Kline
postsData.content:
A title doesn't make you a leader.

Your actions do.

Stop waiting for permission to lead.
Lean into these habits that make work easier:

1. Raise the energy of the room
â†³ Enter with purpose
â†³ Eyes up, phones down

2. Be easy to work with
â†³ Make someone's job easier every day
â†³ Replace "someone should" with "I will"

3. Have the courage to say no
â†³ Set boundaries without guilt
â†³ Choose what matters, cut what doesn't

4. Keep your commitments
â†³ Make tiny promises, keep them religiously
â†³ Build trust through consistent delivery

5. Write strategically
â†³ Turn complex ideas into simple messages
â†³ Author team updates before being asked

6. Be relentlessly resourceful
â†³ Fix small problems others complain about
â†³ Create value before anyone requests it

7. Solve problems with selling
â†³ Turn customer problems into clear plans
â†³ Show the impact in simple numbers

8. Learn how to learn
â†³ Study one new part of the business daily
â†³ Turn "I don't know" into "I'll find out"

9. Actively listen
â†³ Make others feel deeply understood
â†³ Ask questions that open new possibilities

Remember:

Leadership isn't given. It's earned.
One small action at a time

ï¸ Share to help someone
 Followfor more

Carousel by

comments.commentText:
The habits youâ€™ve outlined are foundational to becoming the type of person others naturally follow, regardless of role or rank. Hereâ€™s my take on a few:

- Raise the energy of the room: Leaders are emotional thermostats, not thermometers. Your attitude sets the tone for others to follow.

- Keep commitments: Trust is your greatest currency as a leader. Even small broken promises compound into doubtâ€”but small kept promises build loyalty.

- Be relentlessly resourceful: Show initiative. Solve problems proactively, even if theyâ€™re outside your scope. This â€œownership mindsetâ€ is what separates leaders from the crowd.
Joel - love your take on leaders as emotional thermostats and the power of keeping small promises. Whatâ€™s one habit youâ€™ve found most transformative in building trust and loyalty?
Thanks! I'd have to say practicing proactive transparency. Sharing relevant context with your team, especially the â€œwhyâ€ behind decisions, instantly builds trust.
As someone who values proactive problem-solving, I find the idea of being relentlessly resourceful particularly powerful.
Anubrota - many stop at the first resistance. Others remain curious and find a way to solve for yes.

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely agree! Leadership is about actions and impact. Letâ€™s all strive to lead by example and uplift those around us! ğŸ’ªâœ¨
